message.raw:
Improvements to edit columns dialog.

Changes are applied instantly and it can respond to the columns changing mid-edit.
It also maintains its state from one opening to the next (sorting, filter string)

This seemed like the best way to fix a bug (things would break if the columns
changed whilst you were editing which were visible. This was because the dialog
exec_() method doesn't actually bloick the main event loop, in a sense it is just
a copy of that event loop. So I couldn't easily stop new shots arriving and
messing with the column structure whilst we were editing it).

Just making the whole thing dynamic seemed like a good fix and is nice
behaviour too.

Added context menu to show and hide selection in the dialog box too.

message.raw:
Got progress bar working in table view.
Fixed issues with keeping track of column labels, we were not storing
the full tuples and this led to duplicate column creation when the number
of levels in the dataframe's column multiindex changed.

Made loading files much much faster. Are now limited by actual speed reading
the files, I think further optimisation here is not useful.

Added checkbox to set all shots active - not functioning yet

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where lyse.data() could not set the index on the dataframe.
It seems maybe something in pandas changed such that the number of dimensions
had to match exactly, and that the code I submitted ages ago that let you
specify only the first string if all others were empty is being bypassed.
Or maybe not. Maybe it's because I'm using a test shot that has not actually run.

Anyway it works now.

Or maybe not. Maybe it's because I'm using a test shot that has not actually run.

Anyway it works now.

message.raw:
Can now add a shot! Dataframe and qt model are updated with shot data.
Server works but dataframe appears to be malformed for the conversion that
happens on the other side. This is likely because the shot is one that has not
run yet and so does not have many layers to the multiindex.
This should probably be considered a bug though - it should handle it regardless.

Might move the processing server side if that's possible.

methods are written in a re-usable way such that they can be used by the rest
of the program as it is ported over.

Timezone is now looked up instead of hardcoded (removed google's tz module)
Float values are rendered in scientific notation

message.raw:
Fixed bug where figure manager cleanup was not done if the analysis script raised an exception

This bug could lead to hundreds (or thousands) or windows being created if a script which creates one or more figures before crashing was run multiple times before the error in the script was fixed. This is a particular problem for multishot analysis scripts as the exception does not pause analysis execution (FYI I don't think we would want it to pause analysis on multishot errors, the current behaviour in this regard is correct).

The fix is to place the figure manager cleanup code in a "finally" block of a try/except statement so that it is always run regardless of whether the script succesfully made all of the intended figures or not. Any exceptions are still raised as before, and is not handled by the new try/except/finally block.
message.html:
Fixed bug where figure manager cleanup was not done if the analysis script raised an exception

This bug could lead to hundreds (or thousands) or windows being created if a script which creates one or more figures before crashing was run multiple times before the error in the script was fixed. This is a particular problem for multishot analysis scripts as the exception does not pause analysis execution (FYI I don't think we would want it to pause analysis on multishot errors, the current behaviour in this regard is correct).

The fix is to place the figure manager cleanup code in a "finally" block of a try/except statement so that it is always run regardless of whether the script succesfully made all of the intended figures or not. Any exceptions are still raised as before, and is not handled by the new try/except/finally block.

values.message:
Fixed bug where figure manager cleanup was not done if the analysis script raised an exception

This bug could lead to hundreds (or thousands) or windows being created if a script which creates one or more figures before crashing was run multiple times before the error in the script was fixed. This is a particular problem for multishot analysis scripts as the exception does not pause analysis execution (FYI I don't think we would want it to pause analysis on multishot errors, the current behaviour in this regard is correct).

The fix is to place the figure manager cleanup code in a "finally" block of a try/except statement so that it is always run regardless of whether the script succesfully made all of the intended figures or not. Any exceptions are still raised as before, and is not handled by the new try/except/finally block.

message.raw:
Now uses runmanager's load_shot_globals() function to get shot globals.

That function applies some hacks that we were otherwise applying in several
places. In particular a new hack allows us to use None as a global value.
It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.

It is stored as a null h5py.Reference object.

The function is backported to runmanager gtk so one need not upgrade runmanager.

I replaced it with a simple text box.

message.raw:
Worked on Routine Box

Started working on a Routine Box where you can set a hierarchy of scripts. Drag/Drop cabaility is almost done, just a few things to clean up like:
* Restore expand state of children
* Handle only moving a parent and a subset of children to a new parent
* Handle drop at bottom of treeview to append to end of toplevel
* Show seom indication of what will happen if the drop is completed (a few options here, such as an indicator line, or dummy child entries, or perhaps relocate on dragMove rather than dropEvent)
* probably other things I've forgotten

message.raw:
Removed manual garbage collection after runs.

This appeared to be exposing what may be bugs in C extensions running in other threads.
gc.collect() ought to be able to be called at any time, but if a badly written C extension has its objects swept out from under it when it wasn't expecting it, it may cause a hard interpreter crash. This is what we were seeing. The most suspect C extension was whatever implements checking the last modified time of files on Windows, but I couldn't narrow it down for sure because inserting printlines modified the timing such that I was unable to reproduce the bug.

At any rate, something in filewatcher.modulewatcher.ModuleWatcher.check_and_unload was causing the hard crash, but it went away when manual garbage collection in lyse was turned off.

We will simply shrug our shoulders at this, wonder why it didn't occur before, and move on.

gc.collect() ought to be able to be called at any time, but if a badly written C extension has its objects swept out from under it when it wasn't expecting it, it may cause a hard interpreter crash. This is what we were seeing. The most suspect C extension was whatever implements checking the last modified time of files on Windows, but I couldn't narrow it down for sure because inserting printlines modified the timing such that I was unable to reproduce the bug.

At any rate, something in filewatcher.modulewatcher.ModuleWatcher.check_and_unload was causing the hard crash, but it went away when manual garbage collection in lyse was turned off.

We will simply shrug our shoulders at this, wonder why it didn't occur before, and move on.

values.message:
Removed manual garbage collection after runs.

This appeared to be exposing what may be bugs in C extensions running in other threads.
gc.collect() ought to be able to be called at any time, but if a badly written C extension has its objects swept out from under it when it wasn't expecting it, it may cause a hard interpreter crash. This is what we were seeing. The most suspect C extension was whatever implements checking the last modified time of files on Windows, but I couldn't narrow it down for sure because inserting printlines modified the timing such that I was unable to reproduce the bug.

At any rate, something in filewatcher.modulewatcher.ModuleWatcher.check_and_unload was causing the hard crash, but it went away when manual garbage collection in lyse was turned off.

We will simply shrug our shoulders at this, wonder why it didn't occur before, and move on.

message.raw:
Commented out old function Run.iterable_globals() since it was not fully implemented yet.
Took advantage of runmanager evaluating all globals to write a new (and for most cases equivalent) function Run.get_globals_expansion()
This returns a dictionary of containing key value pairs of global name and expansion group for all globals that are in an expansion group.
Useful for working out what has been scanned over for automatic plotting!

message.raw:
asdatetime now uses pandas.Timestamp with local timezone.
In __init__.py, the df.convert_objects() call leaves dates as is,
otherwise they get cast to numpy.datetime64 which is undesirable.
Using timezones.py (from github gist) to get the local timezone.
This is dodgy, and if we are going to use timezones, they should in
future be put into the h5 file at compile/run time.

message.raw: lyse now converts paths to local ones with the shared_drive module. the 'filapath' column of the dataframe is a local path. If the dataframe is being used by a different computer, the 'agnostic_path' column is provided, which the client should convert to a local path with the shared_drive module before use.

If the dataframe is being used by a different computer, the 'agnostic_path' column is provided, which the client should convert to a local path with the shared_drive module before use.

message.raw:
Fixes #760. save_result and save_result_array now take optional arguments group
and overwrite, and save_result_array permits retention of existing attributes
when overwriting an existing dataset (via keep_attrs). I've also added a method
save_results_dict(self, results_dict, uncertainties=False) which writes a
dictionary of named results as attributes, with the option to pass a dictionary
of parameter = (value, u_value) tuples which we sometimes use when fitting.
If uncertainties = True, two attributes will get created for each fit parameter:
parameter_name and u_parameter_name.

If uncertainties = True, two attributes will get created for each fit parameter:

and overwrite, and save_result_array permits retention of existing attributes

message.raw:
get_globals_raw was not working (affecting "Diff file" feature of runmanager).
Fixed it and added case for keyword argument 'groups'.
Nominal formatting changes.

message.raw:
Set working directory to lyse folder, resolving symlinks.
Previously, main.pyw would fail when executed from a directory other than
lyse.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug on fresh 64bit windows installs (both win7 and win8) where 32-bit enthough+PyGTK+matplotlib(with GTK support) crash when adding analyses to lyse.

Apparently you need to import gtk before importing matplotlib.pyplot
We don't know why!

Apparently you need to import gtk before importing matplotlib.pyplot
We don't know why!
